head.title: Surface Collective Excitations in Ultrafast Pumpâ€“Probe Spectroscopy of Metal Nanoparticles

article.h1: Surface Collective Excitations in Ultrafast Pumpâ€“Probe Spectroscopy of Metal Nanoparticles

span.span: T. V. Shahbazyan and I. E. Perakis
Department of Physics and Astronomy, Vanderbilt University, Box 1807-B, Nashville, TN 37235

div.p: The role of surface collective excitations in the electron relaxation in small metal particles is studied. It is shown that the dynamically screened electronâ€“electron interaction in a nanoparticle contains a sizeâ€“dependent correction induced by the surface. This leads to new channels of quasiparticle scattering accompanied by the emission of surface collective excitations. In nobleâ€“metal particles, the dipole collective excitations (surface plasmons) mediate a resonant scattering of dğ‘‘italic-ddâ€“holes to the conduction band. The role of this effect in the ultrafast optical dynamics of small nanoparticles is studied. With decreasing nanoparticle size, it leads to a drastic change in the differential absorption lineshape and a strong frequency dependence of the relaxation near the surface plasmon resonance. The experimental implications of these results in ultrafast pumpâ€“probe spectroscopy are addressed. We also discuss the sizeâ€“dependence of conduction electron scattering rates.

Surface collective excitations play an important role in the absorption of light by metal nanoparticles.[1, 2, 3, 4, 5] In large particles with sizes comparable to the waveâ€“length of light Î»ğœ†italic-lambda\lambda (but smaller than the bulk mean free path), the lineshape of the surface plasmon (SP) resonance is determined by the electromagnetic effects.[1] On the other hand, in small nanoparticles with radii Râ‰ªÎ»much-less-thanğ‘…ğœ†italic-R RELOP:much-less-than italic-lambdaR\ll\lambda, the absorption spectrum is governed by quantum confinement effects. For example, the momentum nonâ€“conservation due to the confining potential leads to the Landau damping of the SP and to a resonance linewidth inversely proportional to the nanoparticle size.[1, 6] Confinement also changes nonâ€“linear optical properties of nanoparticles: a sizeâ€“dependent enhancement of the thirdâ€“order susceptibilities, caused by the elastic surface scattering of singleâ€“particle excitations, has been reported.[7, 8, 9]

Recently, extensive experimental studies of the electron relaxation in nanoparticles have been performed using ultrafast pumpâ€“probe spectroscopy.[10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17] Unlike in semiconductors, the dephasing processes in metals are very fast, and nonequilibrium populations of optically excited electrons and holes are formed within several femtoseconds. These thermalize into the hot Fermiâ€“Dirac distribution within several hundreds of femtoseconds, mainly due to eâ€“e and hâ€“h scattering. [18, 19, 20, 21] Since the electron heat capacity is much smaller than that of the lattice, a high electron temperature can be reached during less than 1 ps time scales, i.e., before any significant energy transfer to the phonon bath occurs. Note that in nanometer-sized metal particles and nanoshels, the electronâ€“phonon coupling is weaker than in the bulk.[22, 23] During this stage, the SP resonance has been observed to undergo a timeâ€“dependent spectral broadening.[12, 14] Subsequently, the electron and phonon baths equilibrate through the electronâ€“phonon interactions over time intervals of a few picoseconds. During this incoherent stage, the hot electron distribution can be characterized by a timeâ€“dependent temperature.

The manyâ€“body correlations play an important role in the transient changes of the absorption spectrum.[24, 25, 26] For example, in undoped materials, fourâ€“particle correlations and excitonâ€“exciton interactions were shown to play a dominant role in the optical response for specific sequences of the optical pulses.[27, 28, 29] Correlation effects also play an important role in doped systems.[30, 31] In nanoparticles, it has been shown that in order to explain the differential absorption lineshape, it is essential to take into account the energyâ€“dependent eâ€“e scattering of the opticallyâ€“excited carriers near the Fermi surface.[12] Furthermore, despite the similarities to the bulkâ€“like behavior, observed, e.g., in metal films, certain aspects of the optical dynamics in nanoparticles are significantly different.[15, 12, 17] For example, experimental studies of small Cu nanoparticles revealed that the relaxation times of the pumpâ€“probe signal depend strongly on the probe frequency: the relaxation was considerably slower at the SP resonance.[12, 17] This and other observations suggest that collective surface excitations play an important role in the electron dynamics in small metal particles.

In this paper we address the role of surface collective excitations in the electron relaxation in small metal particles. We show that the dynamically screened eâ€“e interaction contains a correction originating from the surface collective modes excited by an electron in nanoparticle. This opens up new quasiparticle scattering channels mediated by surface collective modes. We derive the corresponding scattering rates, which depend strongly on the nanoparticle size. The scattering rate of a conduction electron increases with energy, in contrast to the bulkâ€“plasmon mediated scattering. In noble metal particles, we study the SPâ€“mediated scattering of a dğ‘‘italic-ddâ€“hole into the conduction band. The scattering rate of this process depends strongly on temperature, and exhibits a peak as a function of energy due to the restricted phase space available for interband scattering. We show that this effect manifests itself in the ultrafast nonlinear optical dynamics of nanometerâ€“sized particles. We perform selfâ€“consistent calculations of the temporal evolution of absorption spectrum in the presence of the pump pulse. For large sizes, the absorption peak exhibits a red shift at short time delays. We show that with decreasing size, the SP resonance developes a blue shift due to the SPâ€“mediated interband scattering of the dğ‘‘italic-ddâ€“hole. We also find that the relaxation times of the pumpâ€“probe signal depend strongly on the probe frequency, in agreement with recent experiments.

The paper is organized as follows. In Section II we review the relevant basic relations of the linear response theory for nanoparticles. In Section III the dynamically screened Coulomb potential in a nanoparticle is derived. In Section IV we calculate the SPâ€“mediated interband scattering rate of a dâ€“band hole. In Section V we incorporate this effect in the calculation of the absorption coefficient. In Section VI we present our numerical results and discuss their experimental implications on the size and frequency dependence of the timeâ€“resolved pumpâ€“probe signal. In Section VII we study the quasiparticle scattering in the conduction band mediated by surface collective modes. Section VIII concludes the paper.

section.h2: III Plasmonâ€“pole approximation in small metal particles

Equation (22), which is the main result of this section, represents a generalization of the plasmon pole approximation to spherical particles. The two terms in the rhs describe two distinct contributions. The first comes from the usual bulk-like screening of the Coulomb potential. The second contribution describes a new effective eâ€“e interaction induced by the surface: the potential of an electron inside the nanoparticle excites highâ€“frequency surface collective modes, which in turn act as image charges that interact with the second electron. It should be emphasized that, unlike in the case of the optical fields, the surfaceâ€“induced dynamical screening of the Coulomb potential is sizeâ€“dependent.

Note that the excitation energies of the surface collective modes are lower than the bulk plasmon energy, also given by Eq.Â (19) but with Ïµm=0subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘š0italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\epsilon_{m}=0. This opens up new channels of quasiparticle scattering, considered in the next section.

section.h2: IV interband scattering mediated by surface plasmons

div.p: We now turn to the interband processes in noble metal particles and consider the scattering of a dğ‘‘italic-ddâ€“hole into the conduction band. We restrict ourselves to the scattering via the dipole channel, mediated by the SP. The corresponding surfaceâ€“induced potential, given by the L=1ğ¿1italic-L RELOP:equals NUMBER:1L=1 term in Eq.Â (22), has the form

math.alttext: \displaystyle U_{s}(\omega;{\bf r},{\bf r}^{\prime})={3e^{2}\over R}{{\bf r}% \cdot{\bf r}^{\prime}\over R^{2}}{1\over\epsilon_{s}(\omega)}.

In this section, we study the effect of the SPâ€“mediated interband scattering on the nonlinear optical dynamics in noble metal nanoparticles. When the hot electron distribution has already thermalized and the electron gas is cooling to the lattice, the transient response of a nanoparticle can be described by the timeâ€“dependent absorption coefficient Î±â¢(Ï‰,t)ğ›¼ğœ”ğ‘¡italic-alpha OPEN:( italic-omega PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)\alpha(\omega,t), given by Eq.Â (2) with timeâ€“dependent temperature.[41] In nobleâ€“metal particles, the temperature dependence of Î±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alpha originates from two different sources. As mentioned in the Introduction, for small nanoparticles this effect is relatively weak. The values of Î³ssubscriptğ›¾ğ‘ italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\gamma_{s} and Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mu were extracted from the fit to the linear absorption spectrum, and the initial condition for Eq.Â (VI) was taken as T0=800subscriptğ‘‡0800italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:800T_{0}=800 K, the estimated pumpâ€“induced hot electron temperature.[12] We then selfâ€“consistently calculated the timeâ€“dependent absorption coefficient Î±â¢(Ï‰,t)ğ›¼ğœ”ğ‘¡italic-alpha OPEN:( italic-omega PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)\alpha(\omega,t), which describes the spectrum in the presence of the pump field. The differential transmission is then proportional to Î±râ¢(Ï‰)-Î±â¢(Ï‰,t)subscriptğ›¼ğ‘Ÿğœ”ğ›¼ğœ”ğ‘¡italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-omega CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus italic-alpha OPEN:( italic-omega PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)\alpha_{r}(\omega)-\alpha(\omega,t), where Î±râ¢(Ï‰)subscriptğ›¼ğ‘Ÿğœ”italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-omega CLOSE:)\alpha_{r}(\omega) is the absorption coefficient at the room temperature.

In Fig.Â 1 we show the calculated absorption spectra for different nanoparticle sizes. Fig.Â 1(a) shows the spectra at several time delays for R=5.0ğ‘…5.0italic-R RELOP:equals NUMBER:5.0R=5.0Â nm; for this size, the SPâ€“mediated dâ€“hole scattering has no effect. With decreasing nanoparticle size, the linear absorption spectra are not significantly altered, as can be seen in Figs.Â 1(b) and (c)]. However, the change becomes pronounced at short time delays corresponding to higher temperatures [see Figs.Â 1(b) and (c)]. This effect is clearly seen in the differential transmission spectra, shown in Fig.Â 2, which undergoes qualitative transformation with decreasing size.

Note that it is necessary to include the intraband eâ€“e scattering in order to reproduce the differential transmission lineshape observed in the experiment.[12] For optically excited electron energy close to EFsubscriptğ¸ğ¹italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:endE_{F}, this can be achieved by adding the eâ€“e scattering rate[34] Î³eâ¢(Ec)âˆ[1-fâ¢(Ec)]â¢[(Ec-EF)2+(Ï€â¢kBâ¢T)2]proportional-tosubscriptğ›¾ğ‘’superscriptğ¸ğ‘delimited-[]1ğ‘“superscriptğ¸ğ‘delimited-[]superscriptsuperscriptğ¸ğ‘subscriptğ¸ğ¹2superscriptğœ‹subscriptğ‘˜ğµğ‘‡2italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-E POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:proportional-to OPEN:[ NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus italic-f OPEN:( italic-E POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) CLOSE:] OPEN:[ OPEN:( italic-E POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus OPEN:( italic-pi italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-T CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:]\gamma_{e}(E^{c})\propto[1-f(E^{c})][(E^{c}-E_{F})^{2}+(\pi k_{B}T)^{2}] to Î³hssuperscriptsubscriptğ›¾â„ğ‘ italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma_{h}^{s} in Eq.Â (27). The difference in Î³eâ¢(Ec)subscriptğ›¾ğ‘’superscriptğ¸ğ‘italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-E POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\gamma_{e}(E^{c}) for Ecsuperscriptğ¸ğ‘italic-E POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endE^{c} below and above EFsubscriptğ¸ğ¹italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:endE_{F} leads to a lineshape similar to that expected from the combination of redâ€“shift and broadening [see Fig.Â 2(a)].

In Figs.Â 2(b)Â andÂ (c) we show the differential transmission spectra with decreasing nanoparticle size. For R=2.5ğ‘…2.5italic-R RELOP:equals NUMBER:2.5R=2.5 nm, the apparent redâ€“shift is reduced [see Fig.Â 2(b)]. This change can be explained as follows. Since here Ï‰sâˆ¼Î”similar-tosubscriptğœ”ğ‘ Î”italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to Delta\omega_{s}\sim\Delta, the SP is damped by the interband excitations. This broadens the spectra for Ï‰>Ï‰sğœ”subscriptğœ”ğ‘ italic-omega RELOP:greater-than italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\omega>\omega_{s}, so that the absorption peak is asymmetric. The dğ‘‘italic-ddâ€“hole scattering with the SP enhances the damping; since the Ï‰ğœ”italic-omega\omegaâ€“dependence of Î³hssuperscriptsubscriptğ›¾â„ğ‘ italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma_{h}^{s} follows that of Î±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alpha, this effect is larger above the resonance. On the other hand, the efficiency of the scattering increases with temperature, as discussed above. Therefore, for short time delays, the relative increase in the absorption is larger for Ï‰>Ï‰sğœ”subscriptğœ”ğ‘ italic-omega RELOP:greater-than italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\omega>\omega_{s}. With decreasing size, the strength of this effect increases further, leading to an apparent blueâ€“shift [see Fig.Â 2(c)]. Such a strong change in the absorption dynamics originates from the R-3superscriptğ‘…3italic-R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endR^{-3} dependence of the dğ‘‘italic-ddâ€“hole scattering rate; reducing the size by the factor of two results in an enhancement of Î³hssuperscriptsubscriptğ›¾â„ğ‘ italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma_{h}^{s} by an order of magnitude.

In Fig.Â 3 we show the time evolution of the differential transmission at several frequencies close to Ï‰ssubscriptğœ”ğ‘ italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\omega_{s}. It can be seen that the relaxation is slowest at the SP resonance; this characterizes the robustness of the collective mode, which determines the peak position, versus the singleâ€“particle excitations, which determine the resonance width. For larger sizes, at which Î³hssuperscriptsubscriptğ›¾â„ğ‘ italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma_{h}^{s} is small, the change in the differential transmission decay rate with frequency is smoother above the resonance [see Fig. 3(a)]. This stems from the asymmetric lineshape of the absorption peak, mentioned above: the absorption is larger for Ï‰>Ï‰sğœ”subscriptğœ”ğ‘ italic-omega RELOP:greater-than italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\omega>\omega_{s}, so that its relative change with temperature is weaker. For smaller nanoparticle size, the decay rates become similar above and below Ï‰ssubscriptğœ”ğ‘ italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\omega_{s} [see Fig.Â 3(b)]. This change in the frequency dependence is related to the stronger SP damping for Ï‰>Ï‰sğœ”subscriptğœ”ğ‘ italic-omega RELOP:greater-than italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\omega>\omega_{s} due to the dğ‘‘italic-ddâ€“hole scattering, as discussed above. Since this additional damping is reduced with decreasing temperature, the relaxation is faster above the resonance. This rather â€œnonlinearâ€ relation between the timeâ€“evolution of the pumpâ€“probe signal and that of the temperature becomes even stronger for smaller sizes [see Fig.Â 3(c)]. In this case, the frequency dependence of the differential transmission decay below and above Ï‰ssubscriptğœ”ğ‘ italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\omega_{s} is reversed. Note that a frequency dependence consistent with our calculations presented in Fig.Â 3(b) was, in fact, observed in the experiment of Ref.12, shown in Fig.Â 3(d).

section.h2: VII quasiparticle scattering via surface collective modes

div.p: Let us now turn to the electron scattering in the conduction band accompanied by the emission of surface collective modes. In the first order in the surfaceâ€“induced potential, given by the second term in the rhs of Eq.Â (22), the corresponding scattering rate can be obtained from the Matsubara selfâ€“energy[37]

At the same time, in this energy range, the width Î³essuperscriptsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘’ğ‘ italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma_{e}^{s} exceeds the mean level spacing Î´ğ›¿italic-delta\delta, so that the energy spectrum is still continuous. The strong size dependence of Î³essuperscriptsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘’ğ‘ italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma_{e}^{s} indicates that, although Î³essuperscriptsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘’ğ‘ italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma_{e}^{s} increases with energy slower than Î³esubscriptğ›¾ğ‘’italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\gamma_{e}, the SPâ€“mediated scattering should dominate for nanometerâ€“sized particles. Note that the size and energy dependences of scattering in different channels are similar. Therefore, the total scattering rate as a function of energy will represent a series of steps at the collective excitation energies E=Ï‰L<Ï‰pğ¸subscriptğœ”ğ¿subscriptğœ”ğ‘italic-E RELOP:equals italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:endE=\omega_{L}<\omega_{p} on top of a smooth energy increase. We expect that this effect could be observed experimentally in timeâ€“resolved twoâ€“photon photoemission measurements of sizeâ€“selected cluster beams.[39]

To summarize, we have examined theoretically the role of sizeâ€“dependent correlations in the electron relaxation in small metal particles. We identified a new mechanism of quasiparticle scattering, mediated by collective surface excitations, which originates from the surfaceâ€“induced dynamical screening of the eâ€“e interactions. The behavior of the corresponding scattering rates with varying energy and temperature differs substantially from that in the bulk metal. In particular, in noble metal particles, the energy dependence of the dğ‘‘italic-ddâ€“hole scattering rate was found similar to that of the absorption coefficient. This led us to a selfâ€“consistent scheme for the calculation of the absorption spectrum near the surface plasmon resonance.

An important aspect of the SPâ€“mediated scattering is its strong dependence on size. Our estimates show that it becomes comparable to the usual Fermiâ€“liquid scattering in nanometerâ€“sized particles. This size regime is, in fact, intermediate between â€œclassicalâ€ particles with sizes larger than 10 nm, where the bulkâ€“like behavior dominates, and very small clusters with only dozens of atoms, where the metallic properties are completely lost. Although the static properties of nanometerâ€“sized particles are also sizeâ€“dependent, the deviations from their bulk values do not change the qualitative features of the electron dynamics. In contrast, the sizeâ€“dependent manyâ€“body effects, studied here, do affect the dynamics in a significant way during time scales comparable to the relaxation times. As we have shown, the SPâ€“mediated interband scattering reveals itself in the transient pumpâ€“probe spectra. In particular, as the nanoparticle size decreases, the calculated timeâ€“resolved differential absorption develops a characteristic lineshape corresponding to a resonance blueâ€“shift. At the same time, near the SP resonance, the scattering leads to a significant change in the frequency dependence of the relaxation time of the pumpâ€“probe signal, consistent with recent experiments. These results indicate the need for a systematic experimental studies of the sizeâ€“dependence of the transient nonlinear optical response, as we approach the transition from boundaryâ€“constrained nanoparticles to molecular clusters.
